nodes.body: Note: I have pushed an update to the lean toolchain because this PR was on a [buggy version](https://leanprover.zulipchat.com/#narrow/stream/113488-general/topic/Potential.20data.20loss.20from.20.60lake.20clean.60.20with.204.2E2.2E0-rc2.2F3/near/397875701) of the toolchain. **WARNING**: checking out old commits of this PR using v4.2.0-rc2 or v4.2.0-rc3 can cause `lake clean` to delete your mathlib folder! If you need to do so, make sure to delete `lakefile.olean` manually before running any `lake` commands.
üöÄ Pull request has been placed on the maintainer queue by jcommelin.

LGTM

maintainer merge
I'm out of time for now

LGTM

maintainer merge

```suggestion
instance (i : Œ±) : Unique ({i} : Finset Œ±) where
  default := ‚ü®i, mem_singleton_self i‚ü©; uniq j := Subtype.ext <| mem_singleton.mp j.2
```
avoids the mess of angle brackets

This is arguably slightly better-typed:
```suggestion
  Equiv.Set.ofEq <| coe_union _ _
```

```suggestion
  (Equiv.finsetUnion s t).trans <| Equiv.Set.union (disjoint_coe.mpr h).le_bot
I'd argue this should be `Equiv.Finset.union` to match `Equiv.Set.union`
I assume there's a reason you didn't just use `[DecidableEq _]` here? If so, can you add it to the docstring?
`DecidablePred` generalizes better to other `SetLike` things. But I was inconsistently using `DecidableEq` in the rest of the file, so I just use that everywhere.

```suggestion
@[simp] theorem updateFinset_empty [DecidableEq Œπ] {y} : updateFinset x ‚àÖ y = x :=
```

It's not clear to me what the benefit of defining this on `Finset` is:
```suggestion
/-- `updateSet x s y` is the vector `x` with the coordinates in `s` changed to the values of `y`.

This is `Set.piecewise` where the left argument `x` is dependently-typed
-/
def updateSet (x : ‚àÄ i, œÄ i) (s : Set Œπ) [DecidablePred (¬∑ ‚àà s)]  (y : ‚àÄ i : ‚Ü•s, œÄ i) (i : Œπ) : œÄ i :=
  if hi : i ‚àà s then y ‚ü®i, hi‚ü© else x i
```

I definitely want to apply this to `Finset`. I need to integrate over a `Pi`-type over this Finset at some point.

Your suggestion means that I need to coerce the `Finset` to `Set`. It also means that all lemmas I want are inconveniently stated in terms of `Set`-operations instead of `Finset`-operations. So I need to add a bunch of rewrites commuting coerions with operations. This makes it less convenient to work with.

The proper way to do this is to define this for all `SetLike` objects, but this is impossible at the moment, as the docstring describes.

> So I need to add a bunch of rewrites commuting coercions with operations.

Shouldn't `norm_cast` handle this?

> The proper way to do this is to define this for all `SetLike` objects

I'd argue this is much worse, because now you need separate lemmas about `updateSet _ (s ‚à© t)` for `Set` and `Finset`, and another seven or so for `updateSet _ (s ‚äì t)` for `Submonoid`, `Submodule`, .... Then you have to repeat this for `bot` and `iInf` and `sInf`.

If you do it for `Set` you only need to write these once, because `simp` turns everything into the set operations for you.

I gave this an honest try to use `updateSet` in our work. It is in https://github.com/leanprover-community/mathlib4/commit/d0aa7ef5d825085f84717d5eb8008c3910b90d3a but it a lot less nice.

In the theorem `marginal_union` I do the following calculation (`s` and `t` are Finsets):
```
(‚à´‚ãØ‚à´_s ‚à™ t, f ‚àÇŒº) x = 
‚à´‚Åª (y : (i : ‚Ü•(s ‚à™ t)) ‚Üí œÄ i), f (updateFinset x (s ‚à™ t) y) ‚àÇ.pi fun i' : ‚Ü•(s ‚à™ t) ‚Ü¶ Œº i'
```
This is true by definition when using `updateFinset`.

When using `updateSet`, I have to be very careful to use `Finset`-unions. If I use `Set`-unions, then there are multiple places where the expression becomes type-incorrect (or it becomes nontrivial to prove that it is equal to the `Finset`-union case).

The rest of the calculation mostly goes through the same, if I'm very careful by explicitly stating where the coercions should be added. Some lemmas I still need to formulate for `Finset` specifically, and sometimes I can use `Set` analogues.

I strongly prefer to keep `updateFinset`. If you don't like this operation, I'd be happy to call it `marginalAux` or something and move it to the `Marginal` file, to be PR'd later. (`marginalAux` was actually the original name, until I thought that this operation might be more generally useful.)

EDIT: "just use `norm_cast`" isn't very helpful, since `updateSet` is a dependently typed function: the type of argument `y` depends on the set `s`, so rewriting the set `s` to an equal set `s'` is already quite painful.

This is not fundamental, but sums are coproducts, hence I'd write this lemma as a map from s + t to s cup t.
The usefulness of this remark may appear in the next lemmas which explicitly prove something about the inverse of this map.
I indeed do use the symmetric version of these equivalences most of the time, so I've reversed them
That one is written in the ‚Äúcorrect‚Äù direction.
I'm not convinced this one is worth having; the space of equivs which can be proved with `Equiv.Set.ofEq` seems too large to justify giving any of them names.
I think it would be worth having a `disjUnion` version of this, since then you could drop the `[DecidableEq Œ±]` assumption.
Then we would need to add `DecidablePred (¬∑ ‚àà s)` to make `Equiv.Set.union` work. I don't see why that's better.
Oh good point, you need to be able to decide which half of the disjoint union an element is in to produce the sum type.

```suggestion
  rw [apply_update P, update_apply, ite_prop_iff_or]
```

pullRequest.title: feat: define `updateFinset` which updates a finite number components of a vector
